data.title: Needed: an event when all grammars are loaded
data.body:
I'm writing a package to let the author of a source file put in a comment to force the file to use a certain grammar (aka "mode" in EMACS). This was the goal of the existing package `file-mode` but that package is severely broken and a total rewrite is needed.  The ruby grammar already has this feature [built-in](https://github.com/atom/language-ruby/pull/90) but my package will work for all grammars.

I have a problem that the grammars are loaded asynchronously and a texteditor can be loaded before all the grammars are loaded.  See my issue #6586.  I can find the mode comment when the texteditor is loaded but there is no way to look up the grammar.

For now I'll kludge it and not look for the grammar list until after a time delay but this will cause the user to see the grammar switch after that delay which is not a good UX.

To finally get to the point, I need an event telling me when the grammars are loaded.  I'll wait until then to look in all the files for the mode comments.

data.title: Disable application menu items when they don't apply to the focused element
data.body: Currently, all application menu items are enabled no matter what element is focused, even if their commands aren't bound to that element or its parents. This can contribute to strange behavior / bugs like #6587. If a command isn't bound to a focused element or its parent elements, then it should be disabled (and maybe also removed from the Command Palette? I think that might be better off in another issue though).

data.title: Deleting A File or Folder Does Not Refresh/Update Tree View
data.body:
This should be a simple bug fix.

When deleting a file, or folder,in Atom it appears to not do anything. You still see the file, or folder, sitting there. What you have to do to update the change, is close the parent folder, and open it back up to refresh the changes.

```
projectname
- images
   - image1.png
   - image2.png
```

If you delete for example 'image2.png', it stays there. Click the arrow on the 'images' folder to collapse the folder in the tree view, and again to expand it, and it will show the file is now gone.

When you delete a file, it should call the same refresh action as expanding does, to reflect the changes immediately.

This happens when deleting both files and folders. You have to manually close and open the parent folder to reflect the changes.

data.title: Fixes for PR 6086
data.body:
See #6086 

@CaptSaltyJack, I went ahead and fixed the tests. I did more research and found that the behavior wasn't the bug it was just an obscure flaw in the tests. They're all fixed now :grinning:

data.title: Normalize short urls for repositories in package.json
data.body:
This adds a dependency and replicates the way npm handles 'shortcut' repository urls in package.json, turning them into urls. 

Closes atom/settings-view#387

data.title: Scroll veneer + selection = odd behavior
data.body:
I posted about this on the discussion boards (https://discuss.atom.io/t/automatic-scroll-disable/16460).

It has been reproduced in `--safe`!
1. Start a new file and add enough text to allow for scrolling vertically.
2. Scroll to the very top of the file.
3. Try to select the last two lines on the screen.

It appears that the scroll veneer takes over and starts to move the screen into view. But because you are still down there, it continues to apply and selects while scrolling rapidly, which is hard to control. This also happens at the top of the screen and must be within the 3 edge lines for the issue to happen.

data.title: Measure gutter width rather than calculating the width
data.body:
The minimap inserts itself in the editor shadow DOM, which makes it look like the gutter to the calculation.

Closes https://github.com/atom-community/autocomplete-plus/issues/394
Closes https://github.com/atom-minimap/minimap/issues/317

data.title: Improve font stack
data.body:
This PR adds `DejaVu Sans Mono` to the Atom font stack. It should fix font issues on Linux. See #4201

The default fonts will be:
- `Inconsolata` on all platforms, but must be manually installed by the user. Otherwise..
- `Monaco` on OS X
- `Consolas` on Windows
- `DejaVu Sans Mono` on most Linux distros. Thx @fvsch.
#### Unpleasant surprises

This change should only affect users on Linux that have not defined a custom font in the settings. But arguably that will be a pleasant surprise.

data.title: Refactor TextEditorPresenter batching
data.body:
As we kept adding features or fixing stuff, our `TextEditorPresenter` has grown more and more complex (as of now it counts more than 1k LOC). As you might imagine, this leads to difficult maintenance and introducing regressions becomes much easier. :fearful:

That said, this layer is not intrinsically convoluted and, therefore, I think we have some chance to make it better. This PR attempts to bring some clarity to one aspect @nathansobo pointed during a conversation and which I totally agree with.

When dealing with batching, I introduced an helper function (`@batch`) which enabled me to, more or less, decorate a function and have it batched automagically. While this removed a bit of duplication, it didn't improve code quality at all, making the batching process look a bit opaque.

The intent of this PR is to replace this mechanism with a simpler one, which solely relies on booleans. I have payed attention to preserve the original behavior but, as illustrated earlier on, it's easy to overlook mistakes and it would be great if you could try this out to spot regressions of any kind. (/cc: @atom/feedback)

Going forward I think that the path should be to split `TextEditorPresenter` into many smaller objects (e.g. one for lines, one for gutters, etc... maybe the structure could even match how we currently organize _UI Components_). This way `TextEditorPresenter` could act as the glue which makes those smaller presenters stick together. If we follow this design I think we can make our test suite even more precise (i.e. keep some integration tests in `TextEditorPresenter` and test each component separately). @nathansobo: what are your :thought_balloon: on this?

My plan is to achieve this incrementally :footprints:: this PR is just the first, tiny step; as we touch related areas of this code we should take the time to give them some :heart:.

Any suggestion, proposal or feedback is very welcome! :bow:
